html:
When faces go virally wrong

AI portraiture and the crisis of the profile picture

These days, if it isn’t viral, it won’t make the cut for an artificial growth in user acquisition. That seems to be the playbook manual for OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, who decided to showcase his latest release, 4o image generation, at the expense of his own face.

In a self-deprecating tweet, he posted:

>be me
>grind for a decade trying to help make superintelligence to cure cancer or whatever
>mostly no one cares for first 7.5 years, then for 2.5 years everyone hates you for everything
>wake up one day to hundreds of messages: “look i made you into a twink ghibli style haha”
- Sam Altman

Within hours, the internet exploded. Anime-like images flooded social feeds — of everyone from Donald Trump to basketball stars, LinkedIn influencers to curious netizens uploading their family portraits into OpenAI’s database. Everyone, it seems, wanted a Ghibli-fied version of themselves.

Our Face: A Universal Interface

People’s obsession with their appearance, particularly their face, is astonishing. Perhaps this behaviour is hardwired in us. From birth, the face is the first interface we learn to trust, to recognize, to read.

The face, after all, is a complex “interface”, with 43 muscles packed in a small surface area. It is responsible for making 10,000 unique facial expressions. That makes it a very interesting subject for anyone to explore.

And so, the face is often viewed as a topic of beauty and art.

Consider how men strive to look for the most attractive people to idolise…
